testimony: The next amnesty applicant is Mr Theron.
Thank you, you may be seated.  Your full names, is it Flip Koenraad?
EXAMINATION BY MS VAN DER WALT

Thank you Chairperson.  Mr Theron, your amnesty application appears in Volume 1, on page 94 to 96 and the application which you bring before this Committee is from page 97 to 101, Annexure A and then the political background and motivation, is Annexure B, on pages 102 to page 109, is that correct?
We have also heard the evidence of Mr De Kock, Mr Pienaar with regard to the two incidents for which you apply for amnesty?
And do you confirm their evidence where it is concerned to you?
There was evidence that the information which was obtained with regard to these two shooting incidents, this information came from a source which you handled, is that correct?
And before we continue any further, you approached me after an application was brought in that the source's name be made known and what was your instruction to me?
I requested you not to make the name known.  My feeling was that I did not want to endanger the person's life and that is the only reason.
And are you convinced that that would be so that the person's life would be endangered?
Yes, that is my feeling Chairperson.
This source who gave you this information, did you have, have you dealt with this source a long time before these two incidents?
I speak under correction, but I would say it would be approximately a year, it may have been less, but approximately one year.
And the information which you received through this source, did you confirm it?

Yes Chairperson, I received several pieces of information from this source with regard to the activities of ANC members and I obtained this information and processed it and I sent it through, through the usual channels to the Regional Head Office and then to Head Office.
And then you apply for amnesty for the first event, the event where the Toyota Corolla was involved?
And in that incident, did you also fire shots?
Do you know of any weapons which were found on these persons or not?
Chairperson, later I realised that weapons were planted, during the incident there were no weapons.
And with regard to the second event, did you also receive information from your source that once again, after the first incident, persons would infiltrate the country?
What was the information that you had?
That armed members of the ANC, trained members and who would be armed, would come into the country Chairperson.
Did you know that it would take place on this specific day, the 12th of June?
And did you convey this information to Mr Pienaar?
And you were also involved in this incident?
That is correct Chairperson, I was there.
My duty during the second incident was to handle the light during the incident, that I supply the lighting Chairperson.
When did you have to switch on the light?
After the vehicle had come to a stop and to switch on the light as quickly as possible.
You also did not fire shots during the second incident?
No, I did not shoot Chairperson.
You knew that in both instances, the people would be lured into an ambush?
Why do you say that that was a deduction?
During the planning it became clear that it would be an ambush and not a roadblock.
You have also made statements for the post mortem inquest?
And you also gave evidence there?
Yes.  For the first incident I testified, and for the second one, I did not Chairperson.
I refer the Honourable Committee to Volume 3(a), that is a statement which you  made, is that correct?
Which page Ms Van der Walt?
Page 1 and 2, excuse me Chairperson.  It was to Brigadier Van Wyk, is that correct?
On page 1, paragraph 4, you mention - that is the fourth line Chairperson - you would arrest the persons, is that correct?
Because you knew they would be shot?
Yes, I knew they would be shot.
In the last paragraph you mention that there was a blue flashlight that was switched on, is that correct?
That was not correct Chairperson, there was no other vehicle and no light there at that stage.
On page 2 you mentioned that Colonel De Kock had shouted that it was the police, is that correct?
No, that is not correct Chairperson.

And in the fourth paragraph from the top Chairperson, you said that you were aware that a Makarov pistol as well as handgrenades were found in the possession of the deceased, that is also not correct?
That is correct Chairperson, that is not correct, there were no weapons.
And did you testify as such during the death inquest?
And then in Volume 5 Chairperson,  on page 110 and 111 and 112 you also made a statement?
Can you recall whom you made the statement to?
I cannot see who did this, but I imagine that it was Brigadier Van Wyk.
That was Daantjie van Dyk, it looks like a D?
And this was in regard to the second incident?
And in the second paragraph Chairperson, at page 110 you mention that you received certain instructions from Major Deetlefs and Warrant Officer Pienaar, you didn't mention Mr De Kock there?
Colonel De Kock was there Chairperson, we  received the instructions from Colonel De Kock amongst others.
On the same page, page 110, paragraph 5...
Excuse me, what Bundle are we dealing with?
It is page 47.  It is the big number that we are looking at.
I am sorry, it is on page 47.
If you could go back, Ms Van der Walt, because I was looking at page 110 and it was obviously the wrong statement.
If you could just ask Mr Theron again the questions concerning this page please.
I see it is page 47 of Volume 5, page 48 and 49 that the statement is on?
And then on page 47, the second paragraph, that is where you mention Major Deetlefs and Pienaar and not De Kock, is that correct?
That is correct, Colonel De Kock was also there.
And then on page 47, paragraph 5, you mention that "I switched on a blue light as well as my flashlight to draw the driver's attention to stop", is that correct?
That is not correct, there was no blue flickering light as well as no other vehicle.
You only had a light, what light did you have?
It was the same light that was earlier discussed, it is a very bright light, a search light that one could handle with your hand Chairperson.
And you say that you did not testify during the second inquest?
I did not testify during the second investigation, Chairperson.
You apply in these two incidents for the murders of these people?
You knew that in both instances that the persons would be killed?
And you also apply for any other offence which might emanate from this offence?
As well as for defeating the ends of justice and perjury?

No further questions, thank you.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS VAN DER WALT
Thank you.  Mr Prinsloo, any questions?

Thank you Mr
Chairman.  Mr Theron, during your involvement with the Piet Retief Security Branch were you tasked with several investigations of terror where MK and ANC were involved?
There were incidents at Sasol II, are you aware there of?
I am aware of that Chairperson.
There were the attacks which I have already put in the Eastern Transvaal, to the previous witness?
Yes, the landmine attacks and the bomb explosions, I am aware of that Chairperson.
Was there a high incident of insurgents coming into the country?
That is correct Chairperson, as far as I can recall from 1985, there was an increase Chairperson.
According to your experience, persons who came into the country in this manner, who came through the fence, and did not come through the border post, were they armed?
And according to your information, members of the ANC were well-trained soldiers?
Did you in the circumstances which reigned in the country, did you see them as the same as a person who was embroiled in a war, part of the Security Forces against the ANC?
And is it so that usually no conventional methods were used to combat the situation?
Did you see this instruction as the execution of your general duties?

Thank you Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR PRINSLOO
Mr Cornelius, do you have any questions?
Thank you  Mr Chair.  Mr Theron, were you the handler of the informer or the source?
And had you for several years worked with this source?
Chairperson, approximately a year, I cannot say exactly how, but approximately one year.
You have tested the quality of the source's information, you were satisfied?
That is correct Chairperson.  Previous information that I received, was also tested with other sources and the source was regarded as a reliable source.
When you received this information, did you process it and submit it to your immediate superior?
And on each turn, was it sent through to Security Head Office in Pretoria?
The specific information with regard to the Piet Retief incidents, was this promoted to Pretoria?
Chairperson, I cannot really recall whether the specific infiltration was sent through in writing, I doubt it actually.
You say you had no doubt that the persons would be armed?
And your information that they would be armed, were conveyed to De Kock and C-Section?

That is correct Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR CORNELIUS
Thank you Mr Cornelius.  Mr Hattingh?

No questions, thank you Mr Chairman.
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR HATTINGH

Thank you Mr Chairman.  My Attorney has just been requested, I am referring to page 99 of the Volume 1, paragraph  8 thereon, just to put something to the witness.   You make the statement here that Colonel De Kock had given Roelf Venter to place arms in the vehicle, this must be a fault because we have heard that Martiens Ras said that he did it and in any case, according to the Attorneys who represent Mr Roelf, he was not even there?  Is that reference to Venter's name a mistake?

Chairperson, yes, after I had heard the evidence, it is quite acceptable to me, the evidence of Mr Ras that it might have been different.  Why it was mentioned was because at a stage it was mentioned that Mr Roelf Venter was there, and I assumed, but I accept the evidence of Mr Ras.

Mr Chairman, then I have just been asked to place on record that the Attorneys appearing for Mr Venter said that they will consider filing an affidavit just to confirm that their client wasn't present.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR BOOYENS
Thank you Mr Booyens.   Mr Knight, do you have any questions?

No questions, thank you Mr Chairman.
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR KNIGHT

Thank you Chairperson, just one or two.   With regard to the statement, that is the false statement which you made in Bundle 5, on page 47 to 49, I see it was done on the 26th of May 1989, it was signed on that date.  Is it also your recollection that it was during that time?
Chairperson, it seems as if it is the 26th of May 1989.
Is it that also your recollection that it was in 1989?
The person before whom you attested to it, do you remember who it was?
It was Brigadier Van Wyk.  It seems like that from the statement and as far as I could recall, it was Brigadier Van Wyk.
If you page to page 52, we will see with regard to Mr Rorich.  His was signed on the 8th of June, it seems as if it was Brigadier Van Wyk?
Can you independently recall, was the statement that you signed here, was it typed and prepared beforehand before you signed it, or do you recall how it happened?

As far as I can recall Chairperson, Brigadier Van Wyk met with us one by one in an office.  I cannot recall whether the statement was prepared later and I signed it, but it could be so, but I cannot recall it.
You cannot recall whether a typed version was prepared beforehand, you cannot recall?

No, I cannot exactly recall what the course of events was, but I recall that he called us into his office and took the statements from us, but the typed version, I cannot recall how it was signed exactly, whether it was directly thereafter.
I also see that your statement was signed in Piet Retief?
Did Brigadier Van Wyk come there?
Yes, he stayed quite a while in Piet Retief during the investigation, Chairperson.
Can you recall whether you saw him once or more than once?
I saw him more than once, he was there for quite some time.

Thank you Chairperson, no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR LAMEY
Thank you, Mr Moerane, any questions?

Thank you Mr Chairperson.  With regard to what my learned friend has been asking you, is it correct that the reason why further statements had to be obtained from you and others by Brigadier Van Wyk, was that Warrant Officer Pienaar had been removed as Investigating Officer by then, as a result of objections from the representative of the families?
That objection appears in Bundle 3(b), Chairperson, it was started in April, on the 24th of April 1989.

From the first page, yes.  The basis is laid in the cross-examination of Warrant Officer Pienaar, which covers a number of pages and his argument and finally a decision that he be removed.  Then of course, there were further things that happened, the car was examined by Captain Young, not so?
Captain, could you just repeat the name?  Young?
Yes, I recall Captain Basil Young was there with the ballistic investigation Chairperson.
And you had to go and reconstruct this scene, do you recall that?
Yes Chairperson, in both instances there was a reconstruction.
Yes.   Even at that stage, you did not disclose the presence of Colonel De Kock as far as the second incident is concerned?

Let's look at your first statement in Bundle 3(a), page 1.   You mention in the second paragraph that you had certain information and you received certain instructions, and the information and the instructions are the following
"... that insurgents or the crossing of two trained ANC terrorists would take place during the evening."
	Do you see that?
Now was that information that was obtained from your source?

Chairperson, I cannot recall exactly how the information went about the two members, I have thought about this much and it could be that, I am not saying it is so, but it could be that I can recall there was information from the same source which would have said that the previous day or - people would have infiltrated there but it was cancelled later to another day, and it may be so that this confusion caused the two specific trained members, Chairperson.
Mr Theron, you would agree that the information that you received, couldn't have involved many infiltrators coming in because it was decided to send a Toyota Corolla which would have a driver?
So why should you  make a mistake about two and confusing it with other information that might have been given at another time?

I cannot recall exactly during this incident Chairperson, but what I do know is that there was more than one occasion which was reported to me that infiltrations would take place which did not happen and it was cancelled.  The issue with regard to the vehicle, it was a bit small, it was on short notice that we had to arrange the transport.  We in any case did not foresee that there would be more than four people infiltrating.
But you see Mr Theron, that is the information that Mr Pienaar sent to his superiors, remember?
Yes, I see that in the statement.  I must just state that the information came from my informer, from me.
That is right.   So the information which formed the basis of this operation, was that two trained ANC cadres were going to infiltrate that evening?

That is how it appears in the report Chairperson.  I have just explained how I view the matter, that it may also be from one of the previous incidents where specific figures were mentioned, but I cannot recall the precise detail.
Well, you see everybody who was involved in that operation and who gives a number, for instance Barnard on page 3, he also talks about "two trained ANC terrorists during that night".
I did not see Mr Barnard's statement.
No, there it is, you can look at it now if you don't believe you.

I can't understand Mr Theron, why you should think that this might be confused information?  I mean it is contained in your statement, it is contained in other people's statements, what is the problem with receiving information that two people were coming in, in your mind, what do you see as a problem in this hearing about saying that your information was that two people would infiltrate rather than four?

Chairperson, there were four persons who came.  I cannot imagine what came in on that day with the information, whether it was two persons or whether this was something that came through on a previous occasion.  It is not really a problem to me, I just want to put it clearly that I obtained information on more than these two occasions that there would be infiltrations from the same source.

Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Ras is to the same effect on page 5 of the same Volume.   The statement taken from him on the 4th of July 1989 by Brigadier Van Wyk.  But you see the significant thing about all the statements is that there is no mention that these people would be armed, is there?
I see in the statement Chairperson, that there would be two armed ANC terrorists, I didn't have time to read the rest of the statements.
Mr Moerane, I am sorry, the fourth paragraph the last sentence refers to the usually well-armed terrorists.
Mr Chairman, could my attention be directed at it.

It is on this first page of Mr Theron's statement, paragraph 4, the last sentence reads
"... orders that we had to be well armed because trained terrorists were usually well armed during crossings,"
	not information but indeed the probability of being armed.

That is right.   At this stage, I was just dealing with information, particular, specific information that had been received.   You had not received information that the people, the two people would be armed?
I did not receive information that said that they would be armed specifically.
But from your past experience you believed that they might well be armed?
I think you have already admitted that you took part in this massive collective perjury?
With regard to the further investigation of this matter and the sequel to the first incident, did you receive further information, in other words after the 8th, from your source?
That is correct.  Once again, I received information after the 8th, that there would be another infiltration.
Wasn't certain information given to you by Lieutenant Mose as to the intentions of the people who sent these people who came on the first occasion?

Yes Chairperson, as far as I can recall Mr Mose informed us that one of these persons who had assisted the insurgents, once again wanted to make use of his services because there would be another infiltration.  I cannot recall whether he mentioned a specific date.
Did he not say that if the first infiltration was a success, then others would follow on the Sunday?
No Chairperson, I cannot recall anything like that.  All that I can recall is that he said that they wanted to make use of him again for further infiltrations.  He did not mention any specific dates.

It was important to keep information about the events of the 8th, particularly the fact that the infiltration was not a success from the point of view of the ANC, secret from them, they shouldn't have known, they mustn't know that it was not successful?
That is correct Chairperson, for further infiltrations, it was essential to keep this story  quiet, the incident.
Not only that, but positive steps should have been taken to put them at risk and assure them that the infiltration had been a success?

Chairperson, it wasn't necessary for the informer to state completely positively that the group had reached its destination, the informer were only responsible for arranging transport, so it wasn't really necessary for the informer to report back, that is how I understood it.
But you know that he did report?
And she misled the ANC, which caused them to send another four people to their death?
That is correct, it wasn't the full truth.
Excuse me Mr Moerane, on what grounds do you know that she reported back to the ANC that the first infiltration had been successful?
Chairperson, I did not say that I knew, but ...
No, but it was put to you that you knew that she reported back to the ANC that the first operation was a success and you answered to that positively.

Let me just state Chairperson what the informer's function was, I believe that she reported it back, because all indications were there that if she had not done so, they would not have made use of the informer's services for the second time.

Sorry Mr Moerane, but I think we need to, in the absence of this implicated person, ask a few questions about this and in her interest I think, or his interest.  This informer was an informer within Swaziland?
Whom from time to time came across the border and provided information to you?

At the stage when the first infiltration took place, would this informer certainly have been in Swaziland or do you have any knowledge that she was in the Republic?  We are speaking this in female form.
Do you have any knowledge whether during the first infiltration on the 8th, where the informer found herself?
During the day of the 8th, she was in the Republic, or he was in the Republic to convey certain information to me Chairperson.
That was the information regarding the infiltration?
In other words the same person would have had to report that transport had been arranged?
You don't know whether this person returned to Swaziland or not?
This person did return to Swaziland.
In order to make those arrangements, to confirm them?
Yes, to make the arrangements, I believe so.
Did you at any stage tell this source of yours that these persons had come through, that you had picked them up and eliminated them?

No Chairperson.  At a later stage, I informed the informer after the first incident that we had found the people, but I did not sketch the circumstances surrounding the incident and where it took place.

What story or what version did you want to leave with this informer, what was the informer supposed to think regarding what had taken place if you did not tell her, that you had arrested the persons in a roadblock and that you had them in detention?

I did not say anything about this incident to the informer, I simply said that the information which the informer had given to me, was positive and that we had also obtained positive results.   I also requested the informer to try again, that if there were going to be more infiltrations, to give me the information so that we could have a greater level of success.  I didn't say anything else.

I am just going to take up your time for a short while longer, but with regard to the background, this informer is referred to constantly, but it has never been explained as to how this informer became an informer.  I want to ask you was any pressure put on the informer to be an informer, did she have a choice or was it under some form of coercion?  Did she provide voluntary information to you?
Did you initially approach the informer to assist you, how did the informer arrive at you, were you the first contact?
Yes, I was the first contact.
Yes, money was handed over for services rendered.
And this source was appropriately registered as an informer?
Thank you.  Haven't you read a statement from the source?
Haven't you read a statement from the source?
Chairperson, I don't understand the question.
We said, Mr Moerane, that we don't want the source identified, I don't want to stop you, but as long as we don't identify it until we have had the opportunity to receive representations from ...

No, I don't intend mentioning the source's name.   May I proceed?  Thank you.   You knew that the source was intimately involved with the people who sent the infiltrators into the country from Swaziland?
She knew of the arrangements and took part in the arrangements, the identification of routes for instance?
You know that she was arrested by the ANC?
Do you know how long after the second incident?
I was aware of it shortly after she was arrested, if the members of the ANC could arrest her in Swaziland, a short while after that, approximately two weeks later, she was abducted.
Yes, that is right, because somebody survived?  Because somebody survived the second incident, the people who were shot at on the Swaziland side, of the two, one survived and lived to tell the tale?
No, I don't believe that had any influence on the matter Mr Chairperson.
But you have heard the evidence?
Yes Chairperson, but I don't believe that the person who survived, would have exerted any influences under these circumstances.
In any event, between the two incidents, you must have had contact with the source?

Chairperson, I cannot really recall any precise dates, but what I do recall is that the informer contacted me telephonically on the 12th, I think it was a Sunday and conveyed certain information to me, on the same day of the second incident.
Did you report back to her about the first incident?

Chairperson, I have already stated here that I mentioned to her that the information that she had conveyed to me, had resulted in a successful infiltration, in the sense of the word that it was successful for our side.  But I did not tell her the circumstances surrounding the infiltration, or that the persons had been killed, or where the incident had taken place.
You see, you reported back to her either that the people were arrested or they escaped or they were eliminated, now which of the three did you report back to her?
Chairperson, once again I simply mentioned that it had been successful, I did not say anything else.
What was she to understand by that?
What did you intend her to understand?
I had no intentions for her to understand anything.
You had an intention, you must have understood what you are conveying to her in a particular sense.  What did you intend her to understand?
Chairperson, I must just state I worked with an informer, I would not have conveyed any unnecessary information to this informer, unless it was absolutely necessary.
Yes, but you have still not answered my question, you have not told this Honourable Committee what you intended her to understand by those words.

Chairperson, I have already stated it clearly, I told my informer that the information that she had conveyed to me, had resulted in a successful plan.  I also requested the informer to communicate the next infiltration as speedily as possible to me, because it was important to me and the rest of our members, nothing else.
Is it possible that she understood that to mean that the people had been killed?
Chairperson, to speculate about the thoughts of the informer, is something that I will not make any statements about, I really don't know.

Really I don't think that that is acceptable, you had contact over a long period of time with this person, you recruited her for a certain action during which trained and probably armed persons would be entering the country.  This informer co-operated with you and gave you full information.  This informer would have had some idea and you would have known what that idea was, regarding your planning, whether you wanted to capture these persons, charge them and detain them or whether you wanted to kill them.  I think that it is important in particular for the informer, what your opinion is about her expectations because if she was under the impression or may have been under the impression that these persons were lured or going to be lured by you into an ambush and that they were going to be killed, and if she knew that she was going to continue with this pattern, she would be sending people to their death, otherwise she would knowingly be sending people into a situation of detention and possible torture and prosecution, you must have some idea regarding what you thought the informer was doing when she was co-operating with you?  You had known the informer for almost a year, do you have an answer for us or do you stand by your statement that you have no idea what may have been going through her mind?

Really Mr Chairperson with all respect, I cannot speculate about what she was thinking.  I gave as little as possible information to her.  This informer really did not know what was going to happen to the persons, she may have drawn inferences but I will stand by that.
Well, I will argue at the end of these proceedings that you are not making a full disclosure, I just want to be fair to you.
Chairperson, I am telling the absolute truth, I can give you the fullest assurance of that.
In other words you are telling this Honourable Committee that you conveyed information to her and you do not know what you intended to convey to her, in effect that is what you are saying?
May I ask another question and follow up on this?  Why didn't you tell her thank you very much for your information, we have killed all these persons?
Chairperson, it may have occurred to me that this person would not be willing to assist again, I conveyed as little as possible information to her.
Are you not saying by that that you didn't think that the informer would have co-operated if she knew that you were shooting people dead?
But you had no impression regarding what you thought the informer thought you were busy with?
The informer knew what we were busy with.
She knew that she was sending people to their death and that you were going to shoot them?
At that stage I doubt whether he or she had that information.

I cannot understand sir that you would say "thank you very much for your information, it was successful", but you have no idea in your mind as to what you wanted the informer to make of that information that you had communicated to her.

I find it tremendously strange that you would tell anybody thank you very much for the information that you gave me, it was successful.  You know if you tell somebody something like that, then you would understand that that person knew where the success lay or at the very least, had some notion of what you were saying about where the success lay.

Chairperson, I can only say that when one worked with informers, one had to be very careful, it also operated on a need to know basis.  From our side in the police or Security Branch, we needed to obtain as much information as possible to combat the ANC in their activities and we had to obtain as much information from an informer as possible.
Was this informer responsible for the transport arrangements with the insurgents?
Yes, that is correct, on the South African side.
And both infiltrations took place at the same place, the transport was taken to the same place?
Yes, thank you, would this be a convenient time Mr Moerane, to take the lunch adjournment?
Thank you, we will now take the lunch adjournment until quarter to two.

(continued)   Thank you Mr Chairperson.   I was still asking you Mr Theron about the period between the 8th and the 12th of June 1988, about the contact you had with your source.   You have told the Honourable Committee that you reported to the source about the success of the mission.
Did you discuss a further infiltration, the one that was to take place on the 12th?
What was the nature of the discussion, what did you say to her and what did she say to you?

Chairperson, as far as I can recall, she only conveyed certain information to me, to the extent that there would be another infiltration and the date on which the infiltration would take place, that members will once again infiltrate and that was what the discussion was about.
Is it correct that she was involved, at least she was to be involved as far as the ANC knew, with the transportation of these people?
Yes Chairperson, the arrangements of the transport on the South African side.
Yes, and they relied on her for transport?
That is in both incidents, the first one and the second?
And the contact was supposed to be a person by the name of Amos?
With the first incident, yes Chairperson.
The Amos whom we know was Lieutenant Mose?
And on the second occasion she reported to the ANC that the person who had transported these people, was Amos' brother, Johannes?
That is correct Chairperson, I can recall that.
And we all know that in fact that was a lie, it was Sergeant Manzini?
After the second incident, did you speak to your source?

Yes Chairperson, we had contact again.  I cannot recall exactly at which stage, but after the second incident it became general knowledge that there were shooting incidents.  I imagine that during that time, I had contacted her again Chairperson.
What report did you give to her after the second infiltration, attempted infiltration?
Chairperson, I cannot specifically what I mentioned to the source, but it was clear, everybody knew what had happened.

No Mr Theron, you must remember that very clearly for several reasons, firstly, she must have been told by the person who survived that there was a shooting incident, secondly, it had been reported in the press particularly in Swaziland, that nine people had been killed, not so?
Yes, so please tell this Honourable Committee the nature of your conversation and what you reported to her, and what her attitude was?

Chairperson, I really cannot recall what was discussed there, but I understand the informer must have heard what the circumstances with regard to the infiltration was, but I can really not specifically recall what I mentioned to the source.  Maybe I should just mention that a handler who handles a source, wants information, not conveying information.  It has to be kept in mind the handling of sources has to be handled very sensitively.  A handler does not always know whether the source might be a double agent and as little as possible information would be conveyed to the informer, except in the case where certain information has to be obtained by the source.
Are you telling us that you also do not know how she responded, how she reacted to these events?
Chairperson, I cannot really recall what the source's feeling was with regard to that.

Sorry Mr Moerane, did you get the feeling that everything was all right with her, or did you get the feeling that she was nervous or worried or didn't you get any sense of feeling at all as to how she was thinking?

Chairperson, as far as I can recall there was a stage when some of the members of the ANC had approached her and requested her to go to another destination, it was outside Swaziland, I suspect it must be Zambia or Mozambique and that she refused to go, so I believe that she must have been nervous.
Didn't she tell you that she was now suspected of being an agent or an informer?
The source did mention that Chairperson.
Didn't she ask for protection from you?
She just asked for her money?
On what basis, was she paid a regular salary or was she paid on the basis of the information, on the basis of the number of scalps she delivered?
Chairperson, usually our sources were paid their travelling costs and then claims were laid for services rendered.  An active source would get more money than an inactive source.
